Codeforces Round 1013 (Div. 3) Editorial
By l-_-l, history, 9 months ago, translation,

We hope you liked the problems. Thanks everyone!

Don't forget to praise the sun!

2091A - Olympiad Date

Tutorial

2091A - Olympiad Date

Let's start a digit counter cnt[i] (0≤i≤9). At the moment when 3≤cnt[0], 1≤cnt[1], 2≤cnt[2], 1≤cnt[3], 1≤cnt[5] — the answer is found. If after counting all the digits one of the conditions is not fulfilled, then there is no solution and the answer is 0.

O(n).

Solution
#include <iostream>
 
using namespace std;
 
void solve() {
    int n;
    cin >> n;
    int cnt[10] = {};
    bool f = 0;
    
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        int dig;
        cin >> dig;
        cnt[dig]++;
        if (cnt[0] >= 3 && cnt[1] >= 1 && cnt[2] >= 2 &&
            cnt[3] >= 1 && cnt[5] >= 1 && !f) {
                cout << i + 1 << endl;
                f = 1;
            }
    }
    if (!f) cout << 0 << endl;
}
 
int main() {
    int t;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        solve();
    }
}

2091B - Team Training

Tutorial

2091B - Team Training

Let's assume that there are k people in a team and a[i1] — the student with the lowest skill. Then all other participants will have skill greater than or equal to a[i1]≤a[i2],…a[ik]. The greater the value of a[i1], the fewer people are needed to form a team.

In essence, at each stage after sorting in non-increasing order, we choose whether the current student ai will be the weakest in the team or not. If not, it means that we will put this student aside for now to add someone to the team. If yes, it means that from the put aside students we will add some number so that x≤ai⋅k, where k — the number of students in the team. With each transition to the next student, the size of the team, if he is the weakest — will monotonically non-decrease. And to maximize the number of strong teams — their size should be the minimum possible, which will be suitable for a strong team.

Accordingly, at the moment when we find a student who can be called the weakest in the team, but at the same time the number of team members will allow the team to be strong, then we immediately form such a strong team.

O(n log n).

Solution
#include <iostream>
#include <algorithm>

using namespace std;

void solve() {
    int n, x;
    cin >> n >> x;
    int a[n];
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        cin >> a[i];
    }
    sort(a, a + n);
    reverse(a, a + n);

    int ans = 0;
    for (int i = 0, cnt = 1; i < n; i++, cnt++) {
        if (a[i] * cnt >= x) {
            ans++;
            cnt = 0;
        }
    }
    cout << ans << endl;
}

int main() {
    int t;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        solve();
    }
}

2091C - Combination Lock

Tutorial

2091C - Combination Lock

Let after k cyclic shifts the element pi be at position (i+k)modn. For this point to be fixed, it is necessary that (i+k)modn=pi. Let assume that permutation p is starting from 0, [0,1,2,…,n−1].

From this we get that k=pi−i (mod n). For any cyclic shift to be a fixed point — it must be possible to obtain any k from 0 to n−1. Let us sum both sides for all possible values of k=pi−i (mod n).

We get ∑n−1k=0k=n⋅(n−1)2 and ∑n−1i=0(pi−i)=∑n−10=1pi−∑n−1i=0i=0. In order to construct a permutation, these sums must be equal modulo n, i.e. n⋅(n−1)2=0 (mod n). For even n — this is impossible and the answer is −1. And for odd n one of the options — p=[n,n−1,…,2,1].

O(n).

Solution
#include <iostream>

using namespace std;
 
void solve() {
    int n;
    cin >> n;
    if (n % 2 == 0) {
        cout << -1 << endl;
        return;
    }
    for (int i = n; i > 0; i--) {
        cout << i << ' ';
    }
    cout << endl;
}
 
int main() {
    int t = 1;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) 
        solve();
}

2091D - Place of the Olympiad

Tutorial

2091D - Place of the Olympiad

Let the length of the maximal bench be x, then to maximize the number of desks in one row — we need to put as many benches of exactly x length as possible. There should be an indent after each bench, let's say, that the length of the block is x+1. The total number of such blocks in a row will be ⌊mx+1⌋, and the last bench will have a length of mmod(x+1).

Then the number of desks in one row can reach f(x)=x⋅⌊mx+1⌋+(mmod(x+1)).

Since the rows are independent, there should be k≤n⋅f(x) desks in total. We need to find the minimum x, and since f(x) is monotonically non-decreasing, then the answer can be found using binary search.

(You can also come up with a formula, we'll leave it as an exercise).

O(log k) or O(1).

Solution
#include <iostream>
 
using namespace std;
 
void solve() {
    long long n, m, k, l, r, mid;
    cin >> n >> m >> k;
    l = 0, r = m;
    
    while (l + 1 < r) {
        mid = (l + r) / 2;
        if ((m / (mid + 1) * mid + m % (mid + 1)) * n >= k) {
            r = mid;
        } else {
            l = mid;
        }
    }
    
    cout << r << endl;
} 
 
int main() {
    int t = 1;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        solve();
    }
    
}

2091E - Interesting Ratio

Tutorial

2091E - Interesting Ratio

Let a=gcd(a,b)⋅x, b=gcd(a,b)⋅y for some x and y.

Now F(a,b)=lcm(a,b)gcd(a,b)=a⋅bgcd(a,b)2=x⋅y.

Since F(a,b) — is a prime number, then x⋅y — is a prime number. For x⋅y to be a prime number, then one of the numbers must be prime and the other must be equal to 1. We have the condition that a<b, which means that x=1, and y — is a prime number.

We get that a=gcd(a,b), b=gcd(a,b)⋅y, where y — is a prime number.

The problem becomes the following — count pairs (a,b) such that 1≤gcd(a,b)<gcd(a,b)⋅y≤n. Let's fix y, then gcd(a,b) can take any value from 1 to ⌊ny⌋. Thus, for each prime y, the number of suitable pairs (a,b) is ⌊ny⌋. It remains to enumerate all prime numbers up to n.

With the constraint n≤107, this can be done using the sieve of Eratosthenes.

O(n log log n).

Solution
#include <iostream>

using namespace std;

const int MAXN = 10000001;
bool prime[MAXN];

void solve() {
    int n, ans = 0;
    cin >> n;
    
    for (int i = 2; i <= n; i++) {
        if (prime[i]) {
            ans += n / i;
        }
    }
    
    cout << ans << endl;
}

int main() {
    for (int i = 0; i < MAXN; i++) prime[i] = 1;
    prime[0] = prime[1] = 0;
	for (int i = 2; i * i < MAXN; i++) {
	    if (!prime[i]) continue;
	    for (int j = i * i; j < MAXN; j += i) 
            prime[j] = 0;
	}
	
    int t;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        solve();
    }
}

2091F - Igor and Mountain

Tutorial

2091F - Igor and Mountain

Let's use the dynamic programming method dp[i][j][f]:

  • i — row number.
  • j — column number.
  • f=0 means that exactly one hold has already been selected in the current row, and a second one can still be added (since there are a maximum of two holds per level).
  • f=1 means that two holds have already been used in this level.
  • dp[i][j][f] — the number of ways to construct a correct route starting with a hold in cell (i,j), given that f+1 holds are already used in row i.

For a cell (i,j) with a hold (i.e. s[i][j]= 'X'):

  • At the lower level, i.e. i=n−1, this hold can serve as the start of the route, so all such dp[n−1][j][f]=1.
  • If one hold f=0 is already selected at the current level, then you can take the second hold at the same level at a distance of no more than d, i.e. dp[i][j][f]=dp[i][j][f]+∑j+dy=j−ddp[i][y][1]−dp[i][j][1] (let's not forget to exclude the point (i,j) from the sum, so as not to count it twice).
  • The transition to the next level (if possible) i in i+1 takes a vertical distance equal to 1. So the range of j for the transition will be [j−dx,j+dx], where dx=⌊√d2−12⌋=d−1

    dp[i][j][f]=dp[i][j][f]+∑j+dxy=j−dxdp[i+1][y][0]

This solution recalculates each state in O(d), to make it more efficient — you need to use prefix sums.

O(n⋅m).

Solution
#include <iostream>

using namespace std;

const int MAXN = 2010;
const int MOD = 998244353;

string s[MAXN];
int dp[MAXN][MAXN][2];
long long sdp[MAXN][MAXN][2];

int n, m, d;

long long getsum(int x, int y1, int y2, int f) {
    long long res = sdp[x][y2][f];
    if (y1) res -= sdp[x][y1 - 1][f];
    return res;
}

int get(int i, int j, int f) {
    if (s[i][j] != 'X') return 0;
    long long res = 0;
    if (i == n - 1) res++;

    if (!f) {
        res += getsum(i, max(0, j - d),
                      min(m - 1, j + d), 1);
        res -= dp[i][j][1];
    }

    if (i < n - 1) {
        res += getsum(i + 1, max(0, j - d + 1),
                      min(m - 1, j + d - 1), 0);
    }

    return res % MOD;
}

void solve() {

    cin >> n >> m >> d;
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        cin >> s[i];
    }
    for (int i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
        for (int f = 1; f >= 0; f--) {
            for (int j = 0; j < m; j++) {
                sdp[i][j][f] = dp[i][j][f] = get(i, j, f);
            }
            for (int j = 1; j < m; j++) {
                sdp[i][j][f] += sdp[i][j - 1][f];
            }
        }
    }

    long long ans = 0;
    for (int j = 0; j < m; j++) {
        ans += dp[0][j][0];
    }

    cout << ans % MOD << endl;

}

int main() {
    int t;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        solve();
    }
}

2091G - Gleb and Boating

Tutorial

2091G - Gleb and Boating

Let's consider a simple solution — we will iterate through Gleb's current strength t, from k to 1, and check which positions can be reached using that strength value. For each fixed t, the set of positions can be obtained by any search method, for example, breadth-first search. Next, let's assume that Gleb has turned around and we will start a search from all reached positions with strength t−1 and in the opposite direction. For one strength value, such a search works in the worst case in O(s), so the overall complexity of the algorithm will be O(s⋅k) (which, of course, will take too long) and will require O(s) memory.

Now we need to speed up this solution. First, we need to solve the problem for very large values of s. It is not difficult to prove that if k≥3, then for s>k2, the answer to the problem will be k or k−2. Indeed, let's assume that Gleb with strength k has reached the maximum possible position on the segment. Next, he turns around, takes one step back (with strength k−1). Let's find the position where Gleb will end up if he turns around and moves to the right with strength k−2 until he crosses the boundary s (including the assumption that he can swim beyond s). Let this position be s+r, where 0≤r<k−2. Then, Gleb would need to take another r steps to the left with strength k−1 before the second turn; in this case, he will end up exactly at point s with strength k−2. For this maneuver, he will need a distance of at most k+(r+1)⋅(k−1)<k+(k−1)2<k2.

Thus, for s≥k2, we can obtain either the answer k (which can be checked by simple division) or the answer k−2 (we print it if the answer k is not possible). It is also easy to see that this statement remains true when starting from any point from 0 to s.

Next, we will assume that s≤k2. Let the answer to the problem be ans. Then, if in the algorithm described above we stop the iteration upon reaching point s for some t, the total running time will be O(s⋅(k−ans)). Considering the above, we can assert that ans≥√s−3 (due to the even number of turns, the answer √s−2 may not be suitable). Then the running time of the algorithm does not exceed T=(k−√s)⋅s

We can rewrite this value as follows: (k−√s)⋅s=(k−√s)⋅(√s)2=(2⋅k−2⋅√s)⋅√s⋅√s2

Next, we note that the sum of the factors in the numerator equals 2⋅k, meaning that the maximum value is achieved when they are equal (see, for example, Karamata's inequality). We obtain that: T≤12⋅(2⋅k3)3=4⋅k327

which is already fast enough to pass all tests.

In practice, even in the worst case, the specified algorithm requires even fewer operations and comfortably fits within the time limits.

Solution
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>

using namespace std;

int s, k, p;
vector<bool> was1, was2;

void bfs() {
    vector<int> v;
    for (int i = 0; i < s; i++) {
        if (was1[i])
            v.push_back(i);
    }

    int q = 0;
    while (q < v.size()) {
        int x = v[q++];
        int y = x + p * k;
        if (y >= 0 && y <= s && !was1[y]) {
            was1[y] = 1;
            v.push_back(y);
        }
    }
}

void solve() {
    cin >> s >> k;
    if (s % k == 0) {
        cout << k << endl;
        return;
    }
    if (s > k * k) {
        cout << max(1, k - 2) << endl;
        return;
    }

    was1.resize(s + 1);
    was2.resize(s + 1);
    for (int i = 0; i <= s; i++) {
        was1[i] = was2[i] = 0;
    }

    p = 1;
    was1[k] = 1;
    while (1) {
        bfs();
        if (was1[s]) {
            cout << k << endl;
            return;
        }
        k = max(k - 1, 1);
        p *= -1;
        for (int i = 0; i <= s; i++) {
            was2[i] = 0;
        }
        for (int i = 0; i < s; i++) {
            if (was1[i]) {
                if (i + p * k >= 0 && i + p * k <= s) {
                    was2[i + p * k] = 1;
                }
            }
        }
        swap(was1, was2);
    }


}

int main() {
    int t;
    cin >> t;
    while (t--) {
        solve();
    }
}

Problem D O(1)

void solve(){

ll n,m,k;

cin>>n>>m>>k;

ll total=(n*m-k)/n;

ll kena=m-total;

cout<<(ll)ceil((float)kena/(float)(total+1))<<endl;

}

int main(){

ios::sync_with_stdio(false);

cin.tie(0);

int t=1;

cin>>t;

while (t--)

{

    solve();
}

}

      To minimize the length of the longest bench: Distribute the k students as evenly as possible across the n rows. max = ceil(k/n) Within each row, distribute the students as evenly as possible across the m seats. It is like seperating "max" number of objects(pigeons) using "m — max" seperators, i.e "m — max + 1" holes so ans = ceil(max/m — max + 1)

      +1

      If we used dp[i][y][0], it would mean we are still in the state where only one hold is selected, which contradicts the fact that we are selecting the second hold at y.

      We need to transition to the state where two holds are used, which is captured by dp[i][y][1].

In G, I wasn't able to prove the fact where the answer will always be kk or k−2k−2 for s≥k2s≥k2, so I am posting my solution for the same.

Main thing to note is that for each value of power xx, we only need to consider xx different residues modulo xx, and particularly for each turn around step we only need to consider the maximum xx values we can reach if we are travelling forwards or the minimum xx values if we are travelling backwards. Running complexity is O(k2)O(k2) for each valid kk resulting in overall complexity of ∑ki=1i2=O(k(k+1)(2k+1)6)∑i=1ki2=O(k(k+1)(2k+1)6)

    When it comes to this kind of question it is safe to guess the conclusion, we are almost certain that not all kk will be traversed, and ultimately there must be very few valuable kk, see my submission 312426354, where we note that the run time is very short.

    Edit: I think this problem may be related to the harmonic series, which has only about logklog⁡k valid numbers.

Cool contest!

In fact there are two ways to approach the problem FF: either by counting ways to reach the current 'X' index from the neighboring 'X' indices or vice versa, counting ways to reach the neighboring 'X' indices from the current. The first approach can be implemented with prefix sums and the second via a difference array.

    Yes, if we consider where the dp state can transition to, we can use the difference array to solve it.

Problem D

#include <stdio.h>
int main()
{
    int t;
    scanf("%d", &t);
    int n, m, k, groups, num;
    while (t--)
    {
        scanf("%d%d%d", &n, &m, &k);
        n = (k - 1) / n + 1;        // max num per row (ceil)
        groups = m - n + 1;         // m = (group - 1) + n;
        num = (n - 1) / groups + 1; // num per group (ceil)
        printf("%d\n", num);
    }
}

Problem D O(1)

void solve(){
    int n , m , k;
    cin >> n >> m >> k;
    int ans = m / (( n * m - k) / n + 1);
    cout << ans <<endl;
}

+14

Can G problem be solved in O(K2log(K))O(K2log(K))
My Solution: Submission

Consider that s<k∗ks<k∗k

  • It can be observed that the visitable points form continuous ranges. I try to maintain the visited points as ranges [lx,rx][lx,rx].
  • My claim: number of continuous visited ranges (segments) are <= k, after every turn.
  • Reason: Say power was xx , so adjacent visitable ranges have atmost x gap. So for the next turn with power x−1x−1 the adjacent ranges would definitely merge, new ranges are created only at the boundary points.
  • Propagating the intervals to any multiple of x can be done using sliding window.
  • I am bad at explanation, Correct me if i am wrong anywhere.

    0 
    Even length can not be constructed in the first place, because then the permutation would have more than 1 fixed point per cyclic shift, and thus, 0 fixed point in a certain cyclic shift of the **n** amount we have to do.

An approach I took, was to iterate up 2, which would set each element back by # of times iterated before it can be a fixed ponit, which would allow each to be allocated to a cyclic shift.

The code below is far less elegant than the editorial's, but the guess/indirect proof allowed me to solve it, and co-align with the editorial's intuition about **k**, # of cyclic shifts to be a fixed point, to be any number within 1 to n. I hope this helps.

    ~~~~~

    include <bits/stdc++.h>

    using namespace std;

    void solve(){ int n; cin >> n; vector ans;

    if (n % 2 == 0){cout << -1; return;}

//so using the indirect proof/guess seen in the example
//being that if we iterate two ahead, and append such, they will be ith away from their respective positions in the original permutation, ith being defined as their new position in their new permutation

for (int i = 1; i <= n; i += 2){ans.push_back(i);}
for (int i = 2; i <= n; i += 2){ans.push_back(i);}

for (int i = 0; i < n; i++){cout << ans[i] << ' ';}

    };

    int main(){ int t; cin >> t; while (t--){solve(); cout << '\n';} return 0; }~~~~~

There is an O(1) solution for D. It is as follows (Python 3):

for _ in range(int(input())):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    distribute = -(-k // n)
    groups = m - distribute + 1
    ans = -(-distribute // groups)
    print(ans)

+1
F using DP+prefixSum + difference array
const int mod = 998244353;
void solve(){
    int n,m,d;cin>>n>>m>>d;
    string s[n];
    for(int i=0;i<n;i++){
        cin>>s[i];
    }
    vector<vector<int>>dp(n,vector<int>(m,0));
    for(int i=0;i<m;i++){
        if(s[n-1][i] == 'X'){
            //add 1 from i-d to i+d
            dp[n-1][max(i-d,0ll)]+=1;
            dp[n-1][max(i-d,0ll)]%=mod;
            if(i+d+1 <= m-1){
                dp[n-1][i+d+1]-=1;
                dp[n-1][i+d+1] = (dp[n-1][i+d+1] + mod)%mod;
            }
            
        }
    }
    vector<int>preSum(m,0);
    for(int i=0;i<m;i++){
        if(i) dp[n-1][i]+=dp[n-1][i-1];
        dp[n-1][i]%=mod;
    }
    for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
        if(s[n-1][j] != 'X'){
            dp[n-1][j] = 0;
        }
    }
    for(int i=0;i<m;i++){
        preSum[i] = dp[n-1][i];
        if(i) preSum[i]+=preSum[i-1];
        preSum[i]%=mod;
    }
    for(int i=n-2;i>=0;i--){
        //first we calculate no of ways to come from i+1th row to ith row
        // int temp[m]={0};
        vector<int>temp(m,0);
        for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
            if(s[i][j]!='X') continue;
            //we can come to this j from [i-1][j-sqrtl(d*d -1)] to [i-1][j+sqrtl(d*d-1)]
            int x = sqrt(d*d - 1);
            int lb = max(0ll,j-x);
            int ub = min(m-1,j+x);
            temp[j] = preSum[ub] - (lb==0?0:preSum[lb-1]);
            temp[j] = (temp[j] + mod)%mod;
        }
        for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
            if(s[i][j] == 'X'){//from cur row 
                //add 1 from i-d to i+d
                dp[i][max(j-d,0ll)]+=temp[j];
                dp[i][max(j-d,0ll)]%=mod;
                if(j+d+1 <= m-1){
                    dp[i][j+d+1]-=temp[j];
                    dp[i][j+d+1] = (dp[i][j+d+1] + mod)%mod;
                }
            }
        }
        for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
            if(j) dp[i][j]+=dp[i][j-1];
            dp[i][j]%=mod;
        }
        for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
            if(s[i][j] != 'X'){
                dp[i][j] = 0;
            }
        }
        for(int j=0;j<m;j++){
            preSum[j] = dp[i][j];
            if(j) preSum[j]+=preSum[j-1];
            preSum[j]%=mod;
        }
    }
    cout<<preSum[m-1]%mod<<endl;
}

+18

O(k^2logk) solution for G.

For convenience, we will only consider the round of jumping to the right here. The turn that jumps to the left is symmetrical. If the current jump distance is k0, then for each modulo result of k0, we only need to record the smallest position. Because smaller positions can always jump to larger positions. Next, consider turning at each position. These positions, such as d, d+k0, and d+2k0, must form a cyclic interval in the form of k0-1. What we need to do is to take the maximum value of the cyclic interval for the arithmetic sequence. It can be achieved using a suitable data structure.

    I implemented a similar solution with same complexity. 312517599

    • My idea was to maintain all visitable points as continuous ranges [lx,rx][lx,rx], it can be easily shown that count of such intervals is atmost k, and after updating for every turn, atmost 1 new range (near boundary) gets added to my datastructure.

    • Processing K intervals for each turn (k , k-1 , ... 1) with sorting yeilds the same time complexity

    • If last range is of form [lx,S][lx,S] then this turn's power is the maximal possible answer.

Problem D O(1)

int minimumLongestBench(int n, int elements) {
    int numOfSeparators = n - elements;
    return n / (numOfSeparators + 1);
}

void solve() {
    int n, m, k;
    cin >> n >> m >> k;
    int elementsInMostCrowdedRow = (k % n == 0) ? k / n : k / n + 1; // after deviding on all rows
    cout << minimumLongestBench(m, elementsInMostCrowdedRow) << endl;
}

+11

I think I have a proof that my solution for G (which is basically the same as the editorial solution, but with dynamic programming instead of BFS) works in O(k2)O(k2) per test case.

Let xx be the maximum integer such that s≥x⋅ks≥x⋅k. In other words, xx is sksk, rounded down.

Each value of Gleb's power is processed in O(x⋅k)O(x⋅k), and I claim that after we decrease Gleb's power by O(kx)O(kx), we will find the answer. So, if this claim is true, it works in O(x⋅k⋅kx)=O(k2)O(x⋅k⋅kx)=O(k2).

Let's prove this claim. Initially, Gleb is at point 00 and has power kk. Let's consider the points where he can be after we decrease his power by 22. If he moves ii times to the right, makes a U-turn, moves ii times to the left, and makes a turn again, he will be in point ii. And the maximum possible value of ii is xx, so, after we decrease Gleb's power by 22, he can be in any point from [1,x][1,x] (and possibly some other points we haven't considered yet).

Using a similar argument, we can prove that after we decrease his power by 22 again, Gleb can be in any point from [2,2x−1][2,2x−1], and so on. So, after 2i2i power decreases, there is a segment of length very close to i⋅xi⋅x in which every point is reachable by Gleb with his current power. As soon as this segment's length becomes equal or greater than his current power k−2ik−2i, there will be at least one point pp in this segment such that pmod(k−2i)=smod(k−2i)pmod(k−2i)=smod(k−2i), so the point ss will be reachable with current power. If we take i=kxi=kx, the length of the segment will be very close to x⋅kx=kx⋅kx=k.

Once again，my last solved problem was hacked. I have already used prefix sum to reduce the time complexity,why it still got a TLE? And how to rectify it?

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using namespace std;
#define int long long
char ap[2001][2001];
int sum[2001][2001];
int sum2[2001][2001];
int dp[2001][2001][2];
const int mod = 998244353;

signed main()
{

    ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
    cin.tie(0);
    cout.tie(0);
    int tt;
    cin >> tt;
    while (tt--)
    {
        int n, m, d;
        cin >> n >> m >> d;
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++)
        {
            for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++)
            {
                cin >> ap[i][j];
            }
        }
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++)
        {
            for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++)
            {
                for (int k = 0; k <= 1; k++)
                {
                    dp[i][j][k] = 0;
                    if (i == n && ap[i][j] == 'X' && k == 0)
                    {
                        dp[i][j][k] = 1;
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++)
        {
            for (int j = 0; j <= m; j++)
            {
                sum[i][j] = 0;
                sum2[i][j] = 0;
            }
        }
        for (int i = 1; i <= m; i++)
        {
            if (ap[n][i] == 'X')
            {
                for (int j = max((int)1, i - d); j <= min(m, i + d); j++)
                {
                    if (i != j)
                    {
                        if (ap[n][j] == 'X')
                        {

                            dp[n][i][1] += dp[n][j][0] % mod;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
            sum[n][i] = (sum[n][i - 1] % mod + dp[n][i][0] % mod + dp[n][i][1] % mod) % mod;
        }
        for (int i = n - 1; i >= 1; i--)
        {
            for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++)
            {
                int dis = (int)sqrt(d * d - 1);
                if (ap[i][j] == 'X')
                {
                    int le = max((int)1, j - dis);
                    int ri = min(m, j + dis);
                    dp[i][j][0] = (dp[i][j][0] % mod + (sum[i + 1][ri] - sum[i + 1][le - 1] + mod) % mod) % mod;
                   
                } sum2[i][j] = (sum2[i][j - 1] % mod + dp[i][j][0] % mod) % mod ;
            }
           for (int j = 1; j <= m; j++)
            {
                if (ap[i][j] == 'X')
                {
                    int le = max((int)1, j - d);
                    int ri = min(m, j + d);
                    dp[i][j][1] = (dp[i][j][1] % mod + (sum2[i][ri] - sum2[i][le - 1] - dp[i][j][0] + mod) % mod) % mod;
                   
                }
                sum[i][j] = (sum[i][j - 1] % mod + dp[i][j][0] % mod + dp[i][j][1] % mod) % mod;
            }
        }

        int ans = 0;
        for (int i = 1; i <= m; i++)
        {
            ans = (ans % mod + dp[1][i][0] % mod + dp[1][i][1] % mod) % mod;
        }
        cout << ans << endl;
    }
}

            Let a[i] be the index of value i in the permutation. Then value i will be in the correct spot of the cyclic shift (i-a[i]) % n to the right. Then, the problem requires that each value of (i-a[i]) % n be distinct. One easy way to do this is to have (i−a[i])=−i(modn)(i−a[i])=−i(modn), which means that a[i]=2i(modn)a[i]=2i(modn) (which is your first pattern). Obviously, this only works in distinct values for odd nn.

a=gcd(a,b)⋅x, b=gcd(a,b)⋅y for some x and y Where does this come from

    aa is some number. Also bb is some number

    The problem requires us to work with gcd(a,b)gcd(a,b)

    What does it mean for both aa and bb to have a number, say gg, as their greatest common divisor? It must be that:

    • aa is a multiple of gg
    • bb is also a multiple of gg

    So this means that:

    • aa is gxgx
    • bb is gygy

    where gg is gcd(a,b)gcd(a,b)

    As a side note, I don't know about you, but I personally found it more intuitive to start my thinking from these three facts

    1. 1≤a<b≤n1≤a<b≤n
    2. F(a,b)=lcm(a,b)gcd(a,b)F(a,b)=lcm(a,b)gcd(a,b)
    3. F(a,b)F(a,b) must produce a prime number

for problem E , the sum of n overall test cases isnt required to be bounded we can realize that for each number x it has number_of_distinct_primes(x) relations under it which inspires a dp solution where

dp[i] = dp[i — 1] + number_of_distinct_primes(i);

312619387

also another solution for problem G

let dp[i][j] denote the following

for a movement with same parity as k the minimum reachable cell such that its index equals j mod i

for a movement with different parity from k the maximum reachable cell such that its index equals j mod i

ans is the first time a movement with the same parity as K has s % movement is reachable

transitions are kind of hard to explain honestly but i'll leave a submission and if maybe i've time later i'll explain them

312626019

complexity o(k * k * log(k))

Proof for the problem G : ans = max(1, k-2) for s > k*k-k instead of s > k*k

  • Let's assume that, there are extra 'n' positions remains at last (i.e. n%k), where n < k i.e. max(n) = k-1
  • Let's name those positions '1' to 'n', now to reach '1' we need one move backward from the very last multiple of k, then to reach '2' we need two backward move from the very last multiple of k again, and so on... to reach 'n' we need n moves backwards similarly from very last multiple of k
  • And by ensuring s > k*(k-1) we always have 'n' backward moves available as max(n) = k-1;

I know there are solutions with s > k*(k-2), proof this bound at your own

Problem F — Why my solution is timing out despite being O(n*m)?

Solution:

#include<bits/stdc++.h>
#define fast ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false);cin.tie(NULL);cout.tie(NULL);srand(time(NULL));
#define ll long long int
#define loop(i,a,b) for(ll i=a;i<b;++i)
#define rloop(i,a,b) for(ll i=a;i>=b;i--)
#define in(a,n) for(ll i=0;i<n;++i) cin>>a[i];
#define vl vector<ll>
#define v2d vector<vector<ll>>
#define pll pair<ll,ll>
#define vpl vector<pll>
#define pb push_back
#define all(v) v.begin(),v.end()
#define dis(v) for(auto i:v)cout<<i<<" ";cout<<endl;
#define l(a) a.length()
#define fr first
#define sc second
#define yes cout<<"Yes"<<endl;
#define no cout<<"No"<<endl;
#define mod7 1000000007
#define testcase int t; cin >> t; while(t--){dfunc();}
using namespace std;
ll binaryMultiply(ll a, ll b,ll M=mod7){ll ans = 0;while (b) {if (b & 1){ans = (ans + a) % M;}a = (a + a) % M;b >>= 1;} return ans;}
ll binaryExponentiation(ll a, ll b,ll M=mod7){a %= M;ll ans = 1;while (b){if (b & 1){if(M>mod7) ans = binaryMultiply(ans, a);else ans = (ans * 1LL * a) % M;}if(M>mod7) a = binaryMultiply(a, a);else a = (a * 1LL * a) % M;b >>= 1;}return ans;}
ll digits(ll num){ll c=0; while(num){num/=10; c++;} return c;}
ll reverse1(ll num){ll dig=digits(num); ll g=0; while(num){g=10*g+num%10; num/=10;} return g;}

ll power(ll a, ll b,ll M=mod7){a %= M;ll ans = 1;while (b){if (b & 1){if(M>mod7) ans = binaryMultiply(ans, a);else ans = (ans * 1LL * a) % M;}if(M>mod7) a = binaryMultiply(a, a);else a = (a * 1LL * a) % M;b >>= 1;}return ans;}
ll mminvprime(ll a, ll M) {return power(a, M &mdash; 2, M);}//for prime M

#include <ext/pb_ds/assoc_container.hpp>
#include <ext/pb_ds/tree_policy.hpp>
using namespace __gnu_pbds;
#define ordered_set tree<ll, null_type, less<ll>, rb_tree_tag, tree_order_statistics_node_update>

#ifndef ONLINE_JUDGE
    #include "debug.h"
#else
    #define deb(x...)
#endif

vector<vector<vl>> dp;
vl sdp,sdp1;
ll mod=998244353;

void init(ll n,ll m){
    dp.resize(n+1,vector<vl>(m+1,vl(2,0)));
    sdp.resize(m+1,0);
    sdp1.resize(m+1,0);
}

void dfunc(){
    ll n,m,d; cin>>n>>m>>d;
    vector<vector<char>> v(n+1,vector<char>(m+1));
    loop(i,1,n+1)
        loop(j,1,m+1)
            cin>>v[i][j];
    init(n,m);
    loop(i,1,m+1)
        if(v[n][i]=='X') dp[n][i][1]=1;
        
    loop(i,1,m+1){
        if(v[n][i]!='X') continue;
        loop(j,1,m+1){
            if(j==i) continue;
            if(v[n][j]=='X' && abs(j-i)<=d) dp[n][i][0]++,dp[n][i][0]%=mod;
        }
        sdp[i]=(dp[n][i][1]%mod+dp[n][i][0]%mod)%mod;
    }
    
    loop(i,2,m+1)
        sdp[i]=(sdp[i]%mod+sdp[i-1]%mod)%mod;

    ll rch=sqrtl(d*d-1);

    rloop(i,n-1,1){
        loop(j,1,m+1){
            if(v[i][j]!='X'){
                dp[i][j][1]=sdp1[j]=0;
            }
            else{
                dp[i][j][1]=sdp1[j]=(sdp[min(m,j+rch)]%mod-sdp[max(0ll,j-rch-1)]%mod)%mod;
                if(dp[i][j][1]<0) dp[i][j][1]=sdp1[j]=dp[i][j][1]+mod;
            }
            sdp1[j]=(sdp1[j]%mod+sdp1[j-1]%mod)%mod;
        }
        loop(j,1,m+1){
            if(v[i][j]!='X'){
                dp[i][j][0]=0;
            }
            else{
                dp[i][j][0]=(sdp1[min(m,j+d)]%mod-sdp1[j]%mod+sdp1[max(0ll,j-1)]%mod-sdp1[max(0ll,j-d-1)]%mod)%mod;
                if(dp[i][j][0]<0) dp[i][j][0]+=mod;
            }
            sdp[j]=(dp[i][j][1]%mod+dp[i][j][0]%mod)%mod;
            sdp[j]=(sdp[j]%mod+sdp[j-1]%mod)%mod;
        }
    }
    ll res=0;
    loop(i,1,m+1)
        res=(res%mod+dp[1][i][1]%mod+dp[1][i][0]%mod)%mod;
    cout<<res<<endl;
    dp.clear();
    sdp.clear();
    sdp1.clear();
}

signed main()
{
    fast
    testcase

}

2091G - Gleb and Boating I solved it in O(k^2 log k). Let's consider the number m (=k-2*j), let's get a dp of size m, where in the index i there will be a maximum or minimum position (depending on where we are going at the moment: left or right) that can be reached and which has a remainder i modulo M. Thus, we will iterate through all q from k to m and update dp, if at some point we have dp[s%m] ==s, then m suits us. Let's call this algorithm for m as check(m) -> true/false. If we consider all the numbers k, k-2, k-4, ..., and for them check(k), check(k-2), check(k-4), ... then false will go first, then true. We'll do a bin search for them and find the answer. If everything is false, we'll output 1.

My solution: 319579708

Problem D O(1):

int main() {
    ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
    cin.tie(0);

    int t; cin >> t;
    while(t--){
        int n,m,k; cin >> n >> m >> k;
        int spots;
        if(k%n == 0) spots = k / n;
        else spots = k / n + 1;
        int splits = m - spots;
        int section_length = m / (splits+1);
        cout << section_length << '\n';
    }

    return 0;
}

D: O(1)


void solve() {
   int n,m,k;
    cin>>n>>m>>k;
    int x=(k-1+n)/n;
   // debug(x);
   int y=(m-x)+1;
   cout<<(m/y)<<endl;
}

My thinking process for problem E is slightly different than the editorial, but using the same fact anyway.

Case a=1a=1: lcm(a,b)=blcm(a,b)=b and gcd(a,b)=1gcd(a,b)=1, thus if bb is prime, it's a valid pair;

Case a>1a>1 and gcd(a,b)=1gcd(a,b)=1: lcm(a,b)=ablcm(a,b)=ab and gcd(a, b) = 1. But abab cannot possibly be prime. Thus, pairs of coprime numbers are invalid.

Case a>1a>1 and gcd(a,b)=k≠agcd(a,b)=k≠a: This is a case where aa and bb are non-coprime, and bb is not a multiple of aa. We prove by contradiction. Assume lcm(a,b)k=primelcm(a,b)k=prime, then lcm(a,b)=a⋅bk=k⋅primelcm(a,b)=a⋅bk=k⋅prime. Let m=akm=ak and n=bkn=bk, then km⋅knk=k⋅primekm⋅knk=k⋅prime, and we have m⋅n=primem⋅n=prime. This is a contradiction. Thus, we proved that for a pair of non-coprime numbers with a gcd smaller than aa, the statement is invalid.

In the end, we are left with only the case where 1<a<b1<a<b and gcd(a,b)=agcd(a,b)=a. It's obvious to pick b=a⋅primeb=a⋅prime.

For implementation, I first generated all the primes up to 1e7, and used binary search to search for the number of primes that can be used to obtain bb while not exceeding nn. This is my submission.
